Chapter 9, Part 3: Distinguishing and Ascertaining, Discussing the Meritorious Dharmas Arisen from the Meditative Absorptions in Dependence on the Meditative Absorptions as the Basis. Among the Meritorious Dharmas, First Discussing the Immeasurables.
Verse:
There are four kinds of immeasurables, because they counteract hatred and so forth.
Loving-kindness and compassion have the nature of non-hatred, joy is joy, and equanimity is non-greed.
Their aspects are, in sequence, bestowing happiness, removing suffering,
rejoicing in sentient beings, and equanimity. They take sentient beings of the desire realm as objects.
Joy is in the first two dhyÄnas, the others are in six or fifty.
They cannot eliminate the defilements, and humans give rise to them. The meditative absorptions accomplish three.
The treatise says:
There are four immeasurables: first, loving-kindness; second, compassion; third, joy; fourth, equanimity.

The reason for the name immeasurable is that immeasurable sentient beings are taken as objects, because these four are able to attract immeasurable blessings, because immeasurable loved results are caused by them.
Some say:
These are able to oppose immeasurable frivolous discourse, and craving, etc., are all called frivolous discourse.
Why are there only four immeasurables and no more?
Because they counteract the four kinds of obstacles that are frequently present.
As a scripture says:

If you practice, cultivate, and do much of loving-kindness, it can eliminate hatred. If you practice, cultivate, and do much of compassion, it can eliminate harmfulness. If you practice, cultivate, and do much of sympathetic joy, it can eliminate dissatisfaction. If you practice, cultivate, and do much of equanimity, it can eliminate desire and hatred. Therefore there are only four.
Hatred is a mental activity that wishes to kill sentient beings and wishes to harm sentient beings. It is called harmfulness.
Addicted attachment to objects is the cause of not delighting in abiding in the various wholesome activities. It is called dissatisfaction.
Arising with defiled delight and pleasure in regard to wonderful desired objects, one is never satisfied. It is called desire and craving.
Among them, loving-kindness and compassion have nonhatred as their nature.
If that is so, what is the difference between these two?

Although their natures are not different, still loving-kindness counters the anger of sentient beings that is the opposite of killing and is manifested as the aspect of joy. Compassion counters the anger of sentient beings that is the opposite of harming and is manifested as the aspect of sorrow. This is the difference between them.
Just as suffering and happiness are the same in being feelings but differ in being harmful and beneficial, therefore their natures are different.
The difference between the natures of suffering and happiness has already been explained, and the same is true of the difference between the two kinds of loving-kindness and compassion.
There are those who say
that compassion is non-harmfulness, because it is the proximate antidote to harmfulness.
This is really so, but harmfulness is similar to anger, and compassion is said to be the aspect of non-anger.
It is also similar to non-hatred, and the name non-hatred is established for it. In reality, it is non-harmfulness.
The ancient masters say:
Joy is the feeling of joy.
Why is the feeling of joy produced in the contemplator at that time?
If it is based on bestowing happiness, it is no different from loving-kindness.
If it is based on removing suffering, it should be the same as compassion.
Moreover, a scripture says:
Because of delight, joy is born.
Joy is the feeling of joy, as has already been explained.
This mode of activity of joy is the same as that of delight.
What is the difference in meaning between joy and the arising of joy?
If you say that there is a difference in meaning of lower and higher, then pleasure and serenity must also be so, because the reason for the distinction cannot be found.
Moreover, this contradicts the Abhidharma-nyÄyÃ¢nusÄra-Å›Ästra, which says,
What is joy?
It is feeling, conceptualization, volition, and consciousness associated with joy.
The meaning here is that dharmas associated with joy are predominant in joy, and therefore joy is established in general, not feeling. The reason for this is certain.
If joy is the feeling of joy, why is it said to be associated with feeling?
If you say that the Abhidharma-nyÄyÃ¢nusÄra-Å›Ästra takes reason as its standard, then you should recite the original text without error.
This is also not so. In a treatise that takes reason as its standard, one must have the support of a sÅ«tra in order to determine the text.
If it contradicts the sÅ«tras, the reason must be faulty. One should not change the text of the treatise at will.
Therefore this joy is definitely not the feeling of joy, but takes delight as its essence or is simply the absence of greed.
That is, there is a separate craving that is a mental activity, and it thinks in regard to sentient beings:
How can I make all their happiness not be obtained and belong to me?
Joy can eliminate this, and therefore it is noncraving.
Because it must occur together with the faculty of joy, it can be found in three stages, just as regret is associated with sorrow. Joy is also noncraving.

The distinct characteristic of joy is that the mind is not attached to the prosperity of others, and one deeply rejoices in the attainment of others, and it is said to be the antidote to mental heat. Therefore we know that this joy is also by nature noncraving.

The substance of the immeasurableness of equanimity is only noncraving. The difference between this and the third is that it is characterized by the absence of love and hatred and is equally applied to sentient beings, just as when one first enters a forest, one perceives only trees.
The cause of the practice of equality is called equanimity.
If equanimity can also eliminate hatred, how can it be only noncraving, and how does it differ from loving-kindness?
Also, it is admitted that this equanimity is the antidote to lust, but what is the difference between it and the contemplation of impurity?
As for the difference between equanimity and loving-kindness, loving-kindness is able to counteract hatred induced by anger, and its substance is the absence of hatred.

Equanimity is able to counteract hatred induced by craving, and its substance is the absence of craving.ğŸ”½Isnâ€™t it the case that, just as equanimity has the absence of craving as its nature and is also able to counteract hatred induced by craving,
in the same way, loving-kindness has the absence of hatred as its nature and should also be able to counteract craving induced by hatred?
This objection is not valid, because the modes of activity are different.
That is, the mode of activity of equanimity is to oppose both craving and hatred, because it is indifferent to the distinction of friend and foe, and neither love nor hatred arises from it.
It is precisely because of this that equanimity, which is only the absence of craving, is able to counteract craving and also counteracts hatred.
The mode of activity of loving-kindness opposes hatred but not craving, because it evolves with the bestowal of happiness on sentient beings.

Therefore, although both loving-kindness and equanimity oppose anger, loving-kindness conforms to craving, while equanimity is able to oppose harm. Therefore, there is a great difference between these two.ğŸ”½Or, one who cultivates equanimity treats anger that is not in a proper place, while loving-kindness treats anger that is in a proper place. Therefore, there is a difference.
Impurity and equanimity are able to treat sexual craving and other craving, respectively. Therefore, there is a difference.
These four immeasurables do not benefit or harm others. Why are they only good and not indeterminate?

Because they are able to directly counteract craving, hatred, etc., because the characteristics of what is loved and what is not loved cannot attract them, and because they are able to make the mind freely turn.
The essence and characteristics of these four immeasurables have been roughly distinguished.

As for the differences in their attitudes, one contemplates sentient beings as oneself, which is called loving-kindness; one wishes for sentient beings to be free from suffering, which is called compassion; one rejoices in the flourishing of others, which is called sympathetic joy; and one does not think of the characteristics of friends and enemies, which is called equanimity.
Moreover, not observing whether others benefit or harm, one equally regards all as friends, which is called loving-kindness;
one has pity for those who suffer, which is called compassion;
Through the power of resolve, one imagines that sentient beings obtain benefits and avoid harm, and rejoices in this, which is called joy.
Equally observing the characteristics of sentient beings is called equanimity.
If there are distinctions in these four aspects, how can one cause sentient beings to obtain such happiness?
Thinking in this way, one enters the concentration of friendliness.
How can one cause sentient beings to be free from such suffering?
Thinking in this way, one enters the concentration of compassion.
If sentient beings obtain happiness and are free from suffering, wouldn't that be wonderful!
Thinking in this way, one enters the concentration of joy.
Sentient beings are equal, without any distinction of friend or foe.
Thinking in this way, one enters the concentration of equanimity.

If one's wishes are never fulfilled, wouldn't the power of cultivating concentration be wasted?ğŸ”½If one can subdue anger and other [afflictions], how can it be wasted?ğŸ”½Shouldn't it be mistaken? How can it subdue afflictions?
If one wishes for happiness and so forth, how can it be mistaken?

It is said that these do not say that one has already attained bliss, etc., but only by superior resolve, wishing that all sentient beings will attain bliss, etc., one is able to subdue all delusions, and therefore cultivating these four is not in vain.
In the Concentration Collection, four aspects are mentioned. How does one cause them to be endowed as explained above?

As for saying thinking in this way one enters such and such concentration, if this statement refers to the immediately preceding condition, then loving-kindness, etc. should not have the principle of no interval, because they are aroused by separate, separate thoughts.
If they arise together, then it contradicts the statement of entering.

In the stage of initial practice, they are separately drawn out by added effort, but when they reach the stage of completion, there is also arising together. The Concentration Collection refers to the beginning and there is no error in saying that one enters.
As for loving-kindness, etc., what bliss does one wish to attain?
Some say:
One wishes to attain the bliss of the third concentration, because among all blissful feelings, this is the most excellent. If one has not yet realized it oneself, one knows it through hearing.
Some say:
One wishes to attain the wonderful bliss of nirvana, because among all kinds of bliss, this is the most excellent.
Some say:
They wish to attain the bliss of arhatship, because this is already liberated from all afflictions.

Beginners who have not yet realized this bliss, because they have not yet directly realized it, are unable to extend their minds. They only take their own bodies as the object, and wish that all sentient beings will equally realize this bliss according to the bliss they have realized. Therefore, they only take the undefiled bliss that arises in accordance with principle as the object, and wish that others will equally experience it.

If one has already abandoned the bliss one is experiencing as a bhiká¹£u, even if one has not yet attained the true antidote, one still abides in solitude and experiences the bliss of seclusion, which has the power to surpass the joy of the heavenly king and so on. As the verses on the five kinds of bliss say.

Moreover, those who abide in seclusion and diligently cultivate goodness certainly have good attainment that constantly flows like the water of the great ocean filling the continuum, and joy, lightness, and bliss are produced from this.
The object of these four is sentient beings, because they are cultivated in order to eliminate the hatred, etc., that has sentient beings as its object.

That is, in the realm of desire, there are three groups of sentient beings, enemies, friends, and strangers, from whom hatred, etc., is born. When one is indifferent to the distinction of enemy, friend, etc., one is able to subdue the passions of hatred, etc. Therefore the object of these four is sentient beings of the realm of desire and definitely not sentient beings of the realm of form or the formless realm.
Great compassion is by nature the wholesome root of nondelusion. By the power of this root, one is able to have as an object all sentient beings of the three realms.
If the four immeasurables have only sentient beings as objects, why does a scripture say that one thinks of one direction, etc.?
This is so because one extends ones mind in a state of equanimity to all sentient beings in the receptacle world.
These four are categorized as being associated with the realms of desire and form, because a scripture says,
The immeasurables are able to summon the excellent results of BrahmÄ, Åšakra, and a wheel-turning king.

The Abhidharmaprakarana-pada, based on the wisdom attained through cultivation, says that the seven knowledges know the contaminants that are eliminated by the path of cultivation in the realm of form and the universal contaminants.
Other masters say:
The added efforts of these four immeasurables are common to both the realm of desire and the realm of form, but the fundamental ones are only in the realm of form.
As for the different stages on which the four immeasurables depend, if joy is the same as the faculty of joy, it is only attained through cultivation.
They should say that joy is only in the first two trance states, because in other stages there is no faculty of joy.
If joy is different from the faculty of joy, it is common to both thought and the nature of being attained through birth.
They should say that joy is common to the seven stages, because it is also associated with the feelings of pleasure and indifference.
Other masters say that joy is only associated with the feeling of joy.
They should say that joy is only common to the three stages, or else, as in the verse, it is only two and not the others.
The three of kindness, compassion, and equanimity depend on six stages, namely, the four fundamental trance states, the preliminary stage of the first trance, and the intermediate stage.
Some say that they are only in five stages, excluding the preliminary stage, because they are qualities of ease and can only be produced by those who are free of desire.
Some say:

These four are called immeasurable only in the realm of desire and the first trance state, not in other stages, because a scripture says that the immeasurable is called a divine abode. Also, because it is said that one who cultivates the immeasurables is born in the BrahmÄ heaven. Also, because it is said that they summon the results of BrahmÄ, Åšakra, and a wheel-turning king.
Some say:
They are all based on ten stages, namely, the four fundamental meditations, the four preliminary stages of meditation, and the intermediate meditation.
If compassion is also based on the first three meditations, how can it be associated with joy and pleasure?

Because compassion evolves with the mode of activity of dejection toward sentient beings who suffer. It is like the arising of the attention of disgust that is pure. Therefore it is based on the first three meditations.
The attention of reality can accord with the arising of joy, and there is no error in its being associated with joy and pleasure.
How can it be said that it is similar to that attention of resolve?
Doubt is by nature dejection and does not accord with the arising of joy. How can it be admitted that doubt is associated with joy and pleasure?
The attention of resolve is the same as the above, but it is most in accord with joy, because it can attract true attention.
Doubt is not so, because it is in extreme conflict with the truth.
If the former is associated with joy, why not admit the latter?
The attention of resolve should conflict with joy, because it has the aspects of delight, sorrow, and indifference.

Since compassion has the aspect of sorrow, it should not be associated with joy and pleasure, because two aspects of feeling should not occur simultaneously.ğŸ”½In that case, it should not be associated with the feeling of indifference, because indifference has the aspect of being neither delight nor sorrow.
Since it is not admitted that it is not associated with indifference, it is definitely admitted that it is associated with joy and pleasure, because it must be associated with some feeling.

Although it is said that these four can cure anger, etc., they cannot eliminate the acquisition of the passions, because they are born associated with the attention of resolve. Only true attention can eliminate the passions.
Also, this samÄdhi only has sentient beings as its object, and only attention to dharmas can eliminate the passions.
Also, this samÄdhi only has present objects, and only that which has the three times or non-temporal objects as objects can eliminate the passions.
Also, because the path of liberation can be attained, only the uninterrupted path can eliminate the passions.
There is an explanation:
Because it is included in the fundamental contaminated dhyÄnas.
This reason is mistaken, because it should not be said to be three, because it is based on six stages, and because it should not exist in the preliminary and intermediate stages.
Why does the sÅ«tra say that it eliminates hatred, etc.? This is not contradictory.
Because there are two kinds of elimination.

Or because it attracts the path of elimination by its power, that is, it subdues hatred, etc., and attracts the arising of the path of elimination. Therefore, the sÅ«tra says that it eliminates hatred, etc.
If that is so, why does the sÅ«tra say:
By well cultivating loving-kindness, one abides in the fruit of non-return.
Here, the noble path is called loving-kindness, just as elsewhere it is called conception, etc.
Or it is said that they are acquired by the repeated practice of the loving mind after it has been acquired by a saint.
Or it is said that they are acquired by the repeated practice of the loving mind that is cultivated in order to acquire it.

There is an interpretation that these four are based on bodies in the realm of desire and form, but not in the formless realm, because one who is in the formless realm does not have as objects of consciousness enemies, friends, etc., and because one must first have had those as objects in order to cultivate these four.
According to the correct interpretation, they are based only on bodies in the realm of desire, and only humans in the realm of desire can generate them.
If joy is not the same as the feeling of joy, then one who has one must have all four.

If joy is the same as the feeling of joy, then one who has the feeling of joy must have the other three, but not necessarily joy, because one is born in the third trance state, etc., and does not have joy.
When one first generates the four immeasurables in the realm of desire, one first divides sentient beings into three classes, namely, friends, those toward whom one is indifferent, and enemies.
Each of these three is divided into three, namely, superior, medium, and inferior.
Superior friends are those whose spiritual and physical bodies are born from them, and whose heavy kindness is difficult to repay or leave.
The best friend is one with whom one has exchanged both goods and Dharma and who is extremely intimate.
The middling friend is one with whom one has exchanged goods and who is also intimate.
The best neutral person is one whom one has neither seen nor heard of.ğŸ”½The middling neutral person is one whom one has seen and heard of but with whom one has no contact.

The lowest neutral person is one with whom one has had contact but who is neither a benefactor nor an adversary.ğŸ”½The best enemy is one who has taken away one's fame, reputation, life, or close relatives.
The middling enemy is one who has taken away one's life or the necessities of life.
The lowest enemy is one who has taken away the life or necessities of life of one's friends.

Having divided sentient beings into these categories, the beginner who cultivates loving-kindness first generates pure thoughts of bestowing happiness on the best friend. If one's mind is hard and intractable due to the evil intentions formed through beginningless habituation, one will bear deep resentment upon encountering even slight harm.

On the basis of this, you again stop and reflect on the great kindness of sentient beings, and you again arouse the thought of bestowing happiness on them. Through the power of repeated practice, the thought of resentment is forever gone, and the thought of bestowing happiness continues without interruption.
When this has been accomplished, you gradually extend this thought of bestowing happiness to neutral persons, to those who are hostile but not intimate, and to those who are hostile and intimate.

When you have attained an attitude of equality toward the three kinds of relatives, you then extend this thought of bestowing happiness to neutral persons, to those who are hostile but not intimate, and to those who are hostile and intimate. You gradually cultivate the thought of bestowing happiness until finally you attain an attitude of equality toward your worst enemies and your closest relatives, without any distinction. This is called the completion of the cultivation of loving-kindness.
The cultivation of compassion and sympathetic joy should be explained in the same way.

That is, you contemplate the three kinds of suffering that afflict sentient beings and should not add to their suffering. You should only rescue them as if you were rescuing yourself. You gradually cultivate the thought of rescuing them until finally you attain an attitude of equality toward your worst enemies and your closest relatives, without any distinction. This is called the completion of the cultivation of compassion.
When one imagines that sentient beings obtain happiness and are free from suffering, one deeply rejoices as if it were oneself without distinction. This is called the completion of cultivating joy.
When first cultivating equanimity, one first abandons the neutral, not first abandoning enemies and friends, because aversion and love are difficult to abandon.

Moreover, the neutral category increases the power of abandoning. As before, one first abandons the upper level, then abandons the middle and lower levels, and from enemies and friends, from the lower to the middle, from the middle to the upper.
First abandoning enemies is because friends are difficult to abandon.
As a sutra says:
Greed is difficult to eliminate, not so hatred.

In this way, gradually cultivating and practicing equanimity, up to close friends and the upper neutral, universally abandoning the distinguishing characteristics of sentient beings. This is called the completion of cultivating equanimity.

If one seeks the merits of sentient beings, one can quickly cultivate and accomplish loving-kindness, etc., but not if one seeks their faults. Because those who have severed good roots have merits that can be recorded, and rhinoceros-like solitary realizers have faults that can be grasped, because the fruits of previous blessings and offenses are presently evident.
Having explained the immeasurables, next we explain the liberations.
A verse says:
There are eight kinds of liberations, the first three have the nature of non-greed,
two are one definite concentration, four are the good of the formless concentrations,
the liberations of cessation of perception and feeling arise from the subtle and very subtle,
from the pure mind of one's own stage and from the undefiled of a lower stage.
The three objects are visible in the desire realm, the four objects are the categories of the path,
suffering, accumulation, and cessation of one's own and higher stages, non-analytical cessation, and space.
The treatise says:

There are eight liberations: the first is the liberation of the internal perception of form while seeing external forms; the second is the liberation of the internal non-perception of form while seeing external forms; the third is the liberation of the body's realization and full attainment of the pure liberation; the next four are the four formless concentrations as the next four liberations; and the perception-sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception is the eighth liberation.
Among the eight, the first three have non-greed as their nature, because they are close to the antidote of greed.
However, in the scriptures, it is said that they are conceptualizations because conceptualization increases, just as the recollection of past lives removes the conceptualization of form.
Among the three, the first two are transformations of the aspect of impurity, because they take on the aspects of various practices such as blue and rotting.
The third liberation is a transformation of the aspect of purity, because it transforms into the aspect of pure radiance.

When the three are combined with their auxiliaries, they all have the nature of the five aggregates. The first two liberations are both based on the first two meditations, because they can counteract the greed for visible form in the desire realm and the first meditation.
The first two comprehensively include the preliminary stages and the intermediate state, because the first two can be produced in the five stages.
The desire realm and the first trance state have craving for visible form, because it is aroused by the present consciousness of the body.
In order to be liberated from that craving, the first two pure liberations are established in the first two trance states.

In the second and third trance states, there is no eye consciousness, and therefore there is no craving for visible form that is aroused. Therefore the two pure liberations are absent in the third and fourth trance states.

Although the two roots of goodness similar to the first two liberations are found in the desire realm, they are mixed with the craving of the desire realm and therefore are not established as the two liberations.

Although they are found in the third and fourth trance states, they are far removed from their antidote and are weak in power, and they are also subdued by pleasure and purity and therefore are not given the name of liberation.
The third liberation is established on the basis of the fourth trance state, because the mind is clear and pure, free from the eight forms of distraction.
The fourth trance state and its preliminary concentration are called the fourth trance state.

Although similar wholesome roots exist in the lower stages, they are not called liberations because they are not dominant. Because they are mixed with the desire realm's desire and greed, because in the first and second concentrations impurity is suppressed, and because in the third concentration one is deluded by bliss.
Moreover, they are disturbed by the eight calamities.

The next four liberations are, in their order, by nature the wholesome of the four formless concentrations. They are not indeterminate or defiled, because they are not liberations. They are also not by nature scattered wholesome dharmas, because they are weak. The scattered wholesome dharmas are like the mind at the moment of death.
Some say:
There are also scattered wholesome dharmas at other times, but only innate wholesome dharmas, because there is no hearing or thinking.

The eight proximate concentrations and the eight paths of liberation are also not liberations, because they do not turn their backs on the lower stages, because they are mixed with the path of the lower stages, and because they have not completely freed themselves from the contamination of the lower stages.
A scripture says:
Because they transcend the lower.
Some say:
The liberations of the proximate concentrations are also called liberations, because they turn their backs on the lower stages.
However, in other places it is said that only the fundamental samÄdhi is used, because in the preliminary concentrations there is no complete liberation.
The eighth liberation is the samÄdhi of cessation. It is produced by turning away from and despising feelings and conceptualization.
Or, it is produced by turning away from and despising all objects of thought. This samÄdhi appears after the two minds of slight and subtle.
The mind that is opposed to conceptualization is already called subtle, and this mind is even more subtle, hence it is called slight and subtle. After this, the mind enters the samÄdhi of cessation.

That is, the mind of the summit of existence has three grades, namely, the mind of slight conceptualization, the mind of subtle conceptualization, and the mind of slight and subtle conceptualization, because of the distinctions of superior, middling, and inferior grades.
The samÄdhi of cessation appears after the inferior grade. Therefore, after the mind of slight and subtle, one enters the samÄdhi of cessation.
When one emerges from the samÄdhi of cessation, one either produces a pure mind of the summit of existence or one is able to produce a pure mind of the sphere of nothingness.
In this way, the mind of entry is only impure, but one emerges from both impure and pure minds.

The first three of the eight have as objects only form of the desire realm. There is a difference in that the first two take impure form as object, while the third takes pure form as object, because they oppose attachment to sensual desires.
Even though they are inverted, they are good, or they are slightly in accordance with their objects and are not categorized as inverted.
They are called â€œvolitional imaginationâ€ because they are based on little thought and much imagination.
They are also called â€œrealâ€ because they attract the holy paths.

The next four deliverances each have as objects the truths of suffering, of the cause of suffering, and of the cessation of suffering of their own stage and of higher stages, and the path of all stages, nondetermined cessation, and space.
The formless deliverances turn their backs on lower stages and therefore do not have as objects the suffering and cause of suffering of lower stages.

As for the differences in aspects, the first two have the aspect of impurity, the third has the aspect of purity, and none have the sixteen aspects. The formless deliverances are categorized as fundamental meditations and their aspects are either the four aspects of the truths or not.

As for the relationship of the deliverances to the applications of mindfulness, the first three are associated with the application of mindfulness to the body, and the next four are associated with all four applications of mindfulness.
As for the association with cognition, the first three and the seventh are only associated with conventional cognition, while the fourth, fifth, and eighth are associated with eight cognitions.
As for the association with faculties, the first three liberations are associated with joy and indifference, while the next five liberations are only associated with indifference.
As for the distinction of time periods, they all pervade the three time periods.

As for the distinction of objects in time periods, the three liberations that have already arisen and those that can arise each take their own time period as objects, while those that do not arise take the three time periods as objects. The next four liberations take the three time periods as objects, but not as time periods.
As for the distinction of natures, they are all only of the nature of good.
As for the distinction of objects' natures, the first three liberations take the three natures as objects, while the next four liberations take good and indeterminate [natures] as objects.
As for the distinction of learners, etc., the first three and the last two are only neither-trainee-nor-post-trainee, while the middle three liberations all pervade the three kinds [of learners].

As for the objects of learners, etc., the first three liberations only take neither-trainee-nor-post-trainee [dharmas] as objects, while the four [liberations] take the three kinds [of dharmas] as objects.

As for the distinction of being eliminated by seeing, etc., the first three and the last two are only eliminated by cultivation, while the middle three are eliminated by both [seeing and cultivation] and the rest are not eliminated [at all].
The first three are conditioned by the elimination of the passions by cultivation, and the next four liberations are each conditioned by the three kinds of elimination.
The first is conditioned by oneâ€™s own and othersâ€™ bodies, the next two are conditioned by othersâ€™ bodies, and the last four are conditioned by the three kinds of bodies.

As for the difference in acquisition, the eighth and third are acquired only when not previously possessed, and the remaining six are of two kinds. The two kinds are that the noble person acquires them as internal and the ordinary person acquires them as external. The ordinary person acquires them only when not previously possessed. They are called liberations because of many causes and conditions.

That is, one is born in this place after being liberated from that place, or this power is able to attract liberation, or it is the nature of various kinds of liberation, or it is associated with the superior understanding of liberation.
These liberations are based on the bodies of men and women. Both the noble and the ordinary person are able to cultivate and produce them.
Only the samÄdhi of cessation is based on the body of the noble, and among the bodies of the noble, it is common to both the learner and post-learner.
With regard to the question of what sentient beings produce these eight liberations,
If one always seeks to counteract the objects of perception, this is the practice of craving. If one delights in cultivating many paths, such sentient beings can give rise to liberation.
For what purpose do practitioners cultivate liberation, etc.?
In order to make afflictions even more distant, and in order to attain mastery over meditative absorptions.

Having attained mastery, one can then give rise to such qualities as non-conflict, and to the spiritual powers of the sages. By this, one can transform various realms and perform various deeds such as remaining, abandoning, etc.
Having explained liberation, next we explain the spheres of mastery.
The verse states:
There are eight spheres of mastery. The first two are like the first liberation.
The next two are like the second. The last four are like the third.
The treatise states:

There are eight spheres of mastery. Internally having the perception of form, one perceives external forms as few, whether beautiful or ugly. With such perceptions, one has superior knowledge and superior vision of these forms. This is called the first.
Internally having the perception of form, one perceives external forms as many, as extensively explained up to this is called the second.
